content.raw: For anyone following along at home, this collection of images: http://imgur.com/a/xvdad is the output of this relatively vanilla script: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4989/  I think this is a pretty good improvement as is.  The changes still need to be made to cylindrical and geographic, and the notebooks are progressing.  (I have a spherical notebook now.)  I'm optimistic this will be ready in the next few days.

The changes still need to be made to cylindrical and geographic, and the notebooks are progressing. (I have a spherical notebook now.) I'm optimistic this will be ready in the next few days.

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

content.raw: For the last three sets of images, shouldn't the label be "y" along the x axis in all three cases?
content.html: For the last three sets of images, shouldn't the label be "y" along the x axis in all three cases?

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

content.raw: Nope, they're cutting at an arbitrary angle - so r is more accurate.
content.html: Nope, they're cutting at an arbitrary angle - so r is more accurate.

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

content.raw:
I guess I'm confused then.  Clearly the axis labels match the "Sphy" field.  You've also labeled the y-axis "z".

I think it's only correct to label that axis "r" if the x-axis happens to be drawn at z=0.  For all other coordinates "r" is rotated by some position angle.
content.html:
I guess I'm confused then. Clearly the axis labels match the "Sphy" field. You've also labeled the y-axis "z".

I think it's only correct to label that axis "r" if the x-axis happens to be drawn at z=0. For all other coordinates "r" is rotated by some position angle.

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

content.raw:
Hmm. I chose the arbitrary angle in this case to be pi/2, which coincides
with a line along the y axis. If I had chosen it to be pi/4, it would still
be along r, but not along x or y. But it is still along z regardless.

For the case of cutting at a constant theta, we are creating a conic
section, so perhaps that would be better suited either to a coordinate
scaling or a different axis labeling.
content.html:
Hmm. I chose the arbitrary angle in this case to be pi/2, which coincides with a line along the y axis. If I had chosen it to be pi/4, it would still be along r, but not along x or y. But it is still along z regardless.

For the case of cutting at a constant theta, we are creating a conic section, so perhaps that would be better suited either to a coordinate scaling or a different axis labeling.

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

content.raw:
Is ds.slice(2, pi/2) meant to be the phi axis because the axis order is 0=r, 1=theta, 2=phi?  if so, it might be good to clarify in a statement or comment as it is somewhat unclear what is happening here.

In fact, it might be good to clarify exactly what is happening here.  As far as I can tell, you're generating a SlicePlot over the phi=pi/2 plane of the "funfield" nonsensical field centered on r=0,theta=0, and you're displaying the funfield over the range of values 0 to 4.  Right?  That took a little bit to piece out, but maybe i'm just slow.
content.html:
Is ds.slice(2, pi/2) meant to be the phi axis because the axis order is 0=r, 1=theta, 2=phi? if so, it might be good to clarify in a statement or comment as it is somewhat unclear what is happening here.

In fact, it might be good to clarify exactly what is happening here. As far as I can tell, you're generating a SlicePlot over the phi=pi/2 plane of the "funfield" nonsensical field centered on r=0,theta=0, and you're displaying the funfield over the range of values 0 to 4. Right? That took a little bit to piece out, but maybe i'm just slow.

pullrequest.title: Address some shortcomings of non-Cartesian plots

description:
This starts the process of making non-Cartesian plots somewhat nicer in yt.  It includes two major changes:

 * The cylindrical pixelizer now does the sin/cos outside the innermost loop.  I saw a pretty big speedup from this.
 * The coordinate handler objects now all have `image_axis_name` attributes.

Some specific points for review:

 * Do I have the image axes names correct?
 * Should the image axes names be implemented differently, or elsewhere?

This is still a WIP until:

 * Examples of loading non-Cartesian data are included, probably in notebook form.  (@jsoishi sent me a handy set of examples for generating fun data with spherical harmonics, which I will use.)
 * At least the contour callback works in non-Cartesian geometry, which will be somewhat challenging as it will not translate directly.

UPDATE 1: What took 253 seconds to pixelize previously (from Kyle Parfrey) now takes 0.18 seconds, thanks to algorithmic improvements.  I am slightly concerned there may be issues with my bounding box calculation, which is worth looking over.

UPDATE 2: All tests pass now.  I think I am going to write up notebooks demonstrating this, and then remove the WIP tag.  I do not think getting the contours and other callbacks working is going to be in scope for this PR, unfortunately.

UPDATE 3: Added a notebook, and I think this is now ready for review and hopefully acceptance.

UPDATE 4: Responding to comments.

UPDATE 5: Adding a stopgap catch for cylindrical coordinates and the `display_center`.
